docs.snippet: BERLIN, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -- Authorized Nazi sources said today that the Germans were "ready to prove to Roosevelt that we are superior to him in every respect -- even in using gutter language."

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- United States exports in August rose to the highest level of the war period, reaching a total of $455,000000, an increase of 27 per cent compared with July and of 30 per cent compared with August a year ago, the Department of...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- United States exports in August rose to the highest level of the war period, reaching a total of $455,000000, an increase of 27 per cent compared with July and of 30 per cent compared with August a year ago, the Department of Commerce reported today in revised statistics based on geographical areas.

headline.main: AUGUST EXPORTS AT WARTIME HIGH; U.S. Shipments Jumped 27% Over Preceding Month to Total of $455,000,000 71% TO BRITISH EMPIRE Sales to Russia Increased Threefold -- Our Imports Also Showed Gain

docs.snippet: Extreme nervousness prevailed yesterday in the stock market as a result of the first sinking of an American warship since the Navy extended its patrol, and prices cracked as much as 3 points. Assurance by President Roosevelt, however, that this...
docs.lead_paragraph: Extreme nervousness prevailed yesterday in the stock market as a result of the first sinking of an American warship since the Navy extended its patrol, and prices cracked as much as 3 points. Assurance by President Roosevelt, however, that this incident does not change the relations of Washington with the Reich enabled the share list to close slightly above the low marks of the day in trading which was the heaviest of the week.

docs.snippet: Details of a conversation with the German commander of a submarine that torpedoed and sank the Netherlands freighter Marken off Brazil on Sept. 10 were supplied by the ship's master, Captain Anthonie Kokke, when he arrived here yesterday on the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Details of a conversation with the German commander of a submarine that torpedoed and sank the Netherlands freighter Marken off Brazil on Sept. 10 were supplied by the ship's master, Captain Anthonie Kokke, when he arrived here yesterday on the Moore-McCormack liner Uruguay.
